newsitem.title: IRAQ: U.S. halt to oil deal sends Iraqi prices soaring.
newsitem.headline: U.S. halt to oil deal sends Iraqi prices soaring.

text.p: Iraqis, seeing the value of their currency plunge and prices soar, cursed U.S. President Bill Clinton on Wednesday for suspending their country's oil-for-food deal with the United Nations.

Stunned shoppers saw prices of some essential commodities more than double in under 24 hours. By the afternoon it took 1,750 dinars to buy a U.S. dollar, from 1,500 in the morning and as little as 450 earlier this year.
"Clinton's missiles are hitting every Iraqi in the heart and we the ordinary people are the victims. I hate him, hate him, hate him. Why is he taking our food away," said Um Marwan.
Um Marwan came to Shorja to buy sugar, but went home empty handed when told that the price of a kilogram (2.2 lb) of sugar had shot up from 600 dinars two days ago to about 1,300.
The latest U.S.-Iraqi confrontation began last weekend when Iraqi troops pushed into the north to back one group of Kurdish rebels against their rivals.
In retaliation, Clinton has hit Iraq with two waves of cruise missiles and extended a zone closed to Iraqi aircraft to the edge of Baghdad.

Of wider impact for average Iraqis, the U.S. leader also froze Iraq's oil-for-food deal with the United Nations. It would have allowed Iraq to export oil to pay for food and medicine for a population that has been under severe trade sanctions for six years.

The imports funded by the sale of $2 billion of oil over six months would have been used to augment an Iraqi ration system that now meets barely a third of the needs for essential foodstuffs - rice, sugar and flour.
One shopper said: "All this military confrontation I think is meant to destroy the (oil-for-food) agreement."
Iraqi oil exports had been expected to begin by mid-September and news of the halt sent Iraq's volatile currency down and prices of essential foodstuffs up.
A kilogram of rice doubled to 1,000 dinars from 500 and a tray of 30 eggs jumped to about 3,250 dinars from 2,500, almost half the official monthly salary of a civil servant in Iraq.
Despite the blow, there was little visible discontent on Baghdad streets outside of shoppers and few would give views on the U.S. missile strikes.

"They can give an explanation for their rocket attacks but what would they say to the world when they block food reaching hungry Iraqis and milk reaching malnourished children," said Asim Darweesh, a government employee.
At Shorga, Baghdad's main commercial centre, traders said business was almost at a standstill as shoppers shunned goods that were now beyond their reach.
"It is really unfair," one trader said of the halt to the oil-for-food deal. "I feel sorry for these people because most of them cannot afford to buy even a kilogram of sugar."

Early this year Iraq's talks with the United Nations on the oil-for-food plan produced spectacular gains for the dinar, pushing it from about 3,000 to the dollar at the start of the year to a high of 450.
"I am expecting it to slip more and more until it reaches the levels before the oil talks if the U.S. does not change its stand," a money changer said.
